Everyone's playing their own euro game and sorta interacting sometimes. They all collect VP at different geometric rates (probably the main reason this is so popular). At first I thought it was an issue with people not being experienced enough to negotiate. Then I played a tournament and got pretty far, and even these experienced players were stone quiet, refusing to talk or reveal anything. That was quite the wake-up moment.

The inspiration seems to be "what if we took the best parts of euro games and war games, and combined them?!" but to me it feels like the worst parts of each. People are so focused on their over-complicated personal boards that it's hard to interact on the map, and even then people only realize they need to stop a leader once they're close to winning (then it's too late). So one must play it a dozen times just like a euro game just for players to reach any competitive level. Kind of a backwards arc to me, shouldn't the interaction come first? But it's not much a war game either, there's no firm setting involved (less work, more sales!), no specifics or details. To me the most interesting war games have gaps in them, allowing players to fill in the details with roleplaying or research or maybe both. Most importantly, allowing players to actually worry about the other side's intentions instead of optimizing VPs.

So there's a chaotic core but it doesn't matter, this is intended to sell to euro gamers. Some will get really turned off by the combat and others will love it (I don't mind, but it's not gonna convince the former to keep playing when their engine falls apart), but to me there's hardly anything to fight with, since so much of the design is focused on economic engines. It's like the polar opposite of hybrids I do like, where the fighting comes first, and then players realize they need to tinker with that by adjusting their economic builds, and voila strategy emerges. Here it's the problem I have with euros in general: they're so focused on StRaTeGy first that it dominates everything, and then eventually you do tiny optimizations to adjust that. But not after a battle, then it's far toooo laaaate, you gotta do it 2 turns in advance!

This was quite possibly the worst board game experience I have ever had.

Because every faction plays differently, and the faction playstyles and effective strategies are not well explained, you need to have at least one player at the table who is intimately familiar with your faction if you want a chance of succeeding as a new player.

If you do not have this, you have very little guidance on how your particular faction should be played, and unlike other games, you can't just learn from what other players do since they are essentially all playing different games. This means that you're liable to spend multiple hours of gameplay just trying to figure out how to effectively play your faction with little guidance.

This miserable new player experience could be forgiven if the game didn't also take upwards of four hours to play, with very long turns. Strangely, my faction seemed to take very quick turns while everyone else's took ages. In addition there are very few opportunities for interaction on other players' turns. Because of this, in an over three and a half hour game, I spent maybe 15 minutes actually being able to affect the game in any way whatsoever.

I played as the Corvid Conspiracy, and in my nearly four hour game, I was able to do the following:

Craft one item
Battle once
Flip two plot tokens (my faction's main way of scoring points)
Buy one card from the Riverfolk trader

And that's basically it outside of basic actions like movement and card draw.

This is the only game I have ever played that I wouldn't play again if you paid me.

An insanely long teach due to everyone’s factions being different.

Most of the time someone just sneaks across the finish line at the end and it’s super anticlimactic.
Some of the mini games of factions are fun - like the aerie/birds programming - but most aren’t fun/interesting, like the vagabond… but they sure take a long time to learn either way! Hurray!

A 3, I know I'm giving this a three, one of the most popular asymmetrical war games. It's really hard to write about this game, as the art and the concepts in Root are really great. I truly love all the cards and the illustration of the game board; it makes it feel as though the game doesn't take itself too seriously. Which is a nice change for a war game. Really adding to the appeal. And the concepts are really interesting from a game design point of view. I like the role of the Vagabond just walking around in a forest full of fighting, minding their own business. But absolutely capable of interfering with players who get too strong. But the gameplay loop itself is just not enjoyable. It feels like ages waiting for your turn while watching the others mostly doing meaningless things that don't affect you at all. You can't even plan your next move because you never know what a different player will do. Additionally, the game feels tedious. I love long, complex games like Brass: Birmingham, but Root felt like every turn you are just inching forward (if at all). Maybe this game should have been shorter and smaller, making you more aware of what other people are doing, because it doesn't take much from them to win. Anyway, I won't be playing this again, which is unfortunate, as I really wanted to like this game.

I played two learning games of Root. The game looked like an area‑control war game set in a charming woodland world, but once I started playing, it felt very different. Each faction has its own unique rules and interlocking mechanisms, so in practice every player is solving their own little optimization puzzle. There is some interaction on the board, taking control of clearings, removing enemy pieces, but beyond that, everyone seems to be playing their own private game.

It's focused on point optimization and engine‑building, separates players by design and is needlessly complicated. I’ve seen this in other games, and while I can understand why it appeals to some persons, it leaves me cold.

The artwork is beautiful, the components well‑designed, and the production quality is excellent. But underneath that aesthetic charm, Root is not the wargame it appears to be. It's is an needlessly complicated, solitaire eurogame wearing a thematic disguise, or, more precisely, it's four different eurogames in one box.

I suspect it rewards repeated play and deep learning. But I personally have no desire to invest the time to master each faction’s intricate rules when there are other games that offer me more immediate joy.

Pros:
- Having everyone play different systems is interesting, and I think most people will find a play style that aligns with one of the factions
- the art is really good
Cons:
I only have 1 con but it’s a big one. There are big structural problems that make Root unsatisfying and leaves everyone disappointed.
Every faction has exponential growth potential.
This creates two outcomes, either there’s one leader who shoots ahead & is going to win; or everyone gangs up on anyone who is about to get too out of reach. If everyone is smart, and paying attention, the game plays out like the latter. So this cycle is created where one player gets too ahead, everyone focuses one them, and then the field is leveled. The arbitrary victory point condition then leaves people unsatisfied, because the winner is just whomever is lucky enough to pop off last, before the playing field can be leveled.
If there was a more narratively satisfying win condition, I feel like this game would be saved. Because right now the game just ends, and the lucky guy at the top in that moment is deemed the winner. But all the players know, if it continued that the ‘winner’ would be knocked off the top and everyone would be level pegging again.

Playing Root made me realize that I prefer the latter. The initial learning curve, teach, and investment required in Root are very high and at the peak of anything I want from a multiplayer game. I don't like that dynamic of "stamp out, rebuild, stamp out, rebuild" and much prefer the "wrestle until someone spirals out of control" which I felt like Root was lacking. Now for some things I liked. The cards are super simple and work well. They can be used for tableau building or taking actions. The asymmetry is very, very strong. 4 plays

Not as difficult to learn as it at first seems, in part because the various explainers do such a poor job of introducing the game's common elements, which are pretty straightforward.

The complexity comes in all the different rules each faction follows, which make it hard to strategize to beat other factions if you're not already familiar with them. Each faction's balance of complexity and depth tip too far towards complexity; there always seem to be extra provisions on an opponent's current cards that you didn't take into account in your turn, and even for your own turn, it's too easy to overlook some element. When people keep saying 'oops, I forgot, I take one less hit because my current Mood is Stubborn" or whatever, it's the game design smelling suspicious.

Along these same lines, the game chooses to balance everything out using various rates of victory point scoring, instead of more concrete and palpable win conditions. This scoring creates endgame scenarios where the stakes of decisions feel low, and wins seem non-thematic. Building buildings and knocking them down shouldn't be a net gain -- it should matter because of the power those buildings have to fuel a player's engine.

It's worth specifically comparing Root to Small World, which share the same rough level of board complexity and have asymmetric powers. But the faction-specific rules in Small World are simple enough that opponents understand them completely right away, and turns only need a fraction of the analysis. There isn't as much depth, of course, and I appreciate that you can learn to play a Root faction better over time. But I think the overall trade-offs make me want to replay Small World more; the focused factional differences and their thematic clarity greatly add to the satisfaction of a turn well played, and better telegraph the story of who is winning and why.

It's a shame that the various factions here weren't worked into more satisfying form. The "Woodland Alliance", for example, is a grassroots revolutionary movement that foments rebellion that can overthrow local rule in various forest clearings. Sounds neat! Well, no, the rebellions don't really work in a way that has thematic meaning; they're just another arbitrary chit.

So I don't think Root is the masterpiece that some say it is. The components are visually wonderful, and it does have a certain magic. But I find the game bulky, sluggish, inelegant and unsatisfying. I do want to keep playing, but I don't have the feeling of eagerness to refine my playing strategy that I wish I had.

I've seen people posting stuff about this game, declaring it's one of their favourite games to teach others how to play, as it's so easy and it takes them like 15 minutes. Wait, what? I know I never got this good at neither playing 'Root' or teaching others, but it really sounds impossible to me.

I've played several games of 'Root', mostly at 2P (with either my wife or my friend) or at 3P (with both of them), and I was the one who had more knowledge about the way that game and particular factions worked and I still needed to check the rulebook every now and then, and then the otheer rulebook as I didn't really find what I was looking for, and then I needed some time to properly interpret the rules. Well, usually there was... some time between one game of 'Root' and another, so it wasn't easy to get used to even some core concepts... Anyway, I was the only one of us who tried playing as all the possible factions in the base game (+ Lizards from 'Riverfolk' expansion). Others just preferred playing as Birds mostly (my wife) or were relatively good with trying different factions, including some version of the Vagabond (my friend).

The problem is that as it's a highly asymmetric game, it's not easy to play even if you've memorised all the core rules and what's the goal for your faction. You need to know how all the factions used by other players actually work. And that's the problem. I often got accused of winning because... 'you know your faction and know the game more than we do, we can't win this way'. Erm... Oh, and once or twice it was also mentioned that I played solo in the app version. I did it ONCE... I'm not trying to discredit my co-players here, I'm trying to make a general point: there IS a lot to learn and you need some DEDICATION to have fun with this game. Sure, I'm not that good at teaching others, despite being the one doing it most of times; and I know that there are various ways of learning how to play (or learning anything else in life) and some ways just aren't very efficient for everyone. Pitfalls:

I know Root is a big hit, but my desire to play the game has always been low due to two facts. 1. I played Vast a long time ago and I didn´t enjoy it much (perhaps due to a bad explanation) and 2. Playing with asymmetrical armies makes the game hard to explain and hard to get to the table (this remains true), still, I enjoyed the game way more than I though I would, so, I was pleasantly surprised by it.

Root´s rules aren’t very complex, but there are A LOT of different rules so explaining the game takes a long time as each player needs a personalized explanation. This is very cool on theory, but in practice, it is a hassle as you need to make sure all players understand all factions. You can teach the rules in around 30 minutes. Playtime is around 2 hours.

The game´s components are very well done and they look great on the table. The art is also topnotch.

The theme it´s there but I don’t really care much for it.

Root it´s a dudes on a map game and I was pretty sure I was going to dislike it due to this BUT, I didn’t. In Root, each army has a different way to generate VPs and the goal is to achieve 30 VPs, so the game doesn´t feel too long. It is VERY cool that each army plays very differently from each other and I really want to explore them further.

Luck plays a role in the game and this bothers me a bit. The luck of the draw with the cards can decide games (it decided ours). There are some cards that can give a lot of VPs, like Royal Claim (although they are harder to play). There are also dominion cards which gives you an alternate form of victory, but these cards don’t bother me that much. With a couple of games, you will know for sure to be on the lookout for them. To summarize this part, I would have liked it a bit better if the cards power level was more balanced, BUT, in this kind of game, players balance the game themselves (which I kind of dislike). There is also luck with the combat dice but, ironically, this luck doesn’t bother me as you can easily calculate the odds.

Another (minor) dislike for me is that the game gets balanced by the players themselves, that is, everyone attacks the perceived leader, so the best strategy is to go second in VPs until you are ready to spring for victory, this is a common characteristic of area control games and/or dudes in a map games. This also could lead to kingmaking situations so I think it is best played as a 4 player game.

After 1 play, I cannot begin to comment on the power level of the armies, but, again, in this kind of game, this responsibility falls to the players to balance the game themselves, so it doesn’t worry me too much. Having said that, there are some factions that play much easier than others, other factions require more finesse to be played successfully (again, not a bad thing).

It also bothers me a bit that every army has an except that tells players how to play it. I hate this in rulebooks and in player aids. The reason is that I feel this robs me of the opportunity to discover the best strategy for myself, and, even when I don’t read it, when other player do, this affect gameplay a lot. This is, obviously, a personal preference, but would have liked it more if the tips were only in the rulebook. I also get why the designer did this, the game can be complex for new players.

Replayability seems very high, not only each faction plays very differently, the game has lots of expansions.

I'm not sure if Root is a Wargame or not., According to BGG´s definition, it does seem to be a Wargame, and, in this case, it should win the spot for best Wargame (and only game I have played in this category) in my personal 2018 list . As I´m not sure, I´m still not ready to give it the award though.

Bottom line, I was pleasantly surprised by Root, I liked the game enough to keep it in my game collection (for now) and I want to explore it further. It also made me want to play Vast again to see what did I miss the first time. Root is, undeniable, a good game so it deserves its reputation. I, generally, don’t enjoy much this kind of game and having asymmetrical armies makes the game hard to hit the table (due to its long explanation). I imagine it would be bliss to play it often with the same game group (as to avoid the explanation), but, these days, there are almost always new players in our game group. I´m a bit worried about the power level and balance of the cards, but this is a small issue for me (in this kind of game).

Given the high degree of asymmetry between factions, I doubt they will ever be perfectly balanced, regardless of the number of post-release balance changes.

A pity, too, because if the factions were somehow balanced, then this would be a perfect "10".
As it is, the cats fare great in 3 player games but suck at higher player counts, given the faction's fixed action economy. Conversely, the Alliance seems to do better with more players, as more players means more movement into Alliance controlled clearings.

And the Vagabond always seems to fare well, regardless of player count. Since there's never a reward for attacking the vagabond, as there is sometimes when attacking other factions, anyone attacking the vagabond does so at the cost of losing their own tempo. Additionally, in the current state of the rules, if the attacker is an enemy of the vagabond, the vagabond can score points even as the defender, giving a disincentive to attack him.

I understand that "balance" may not be among the designer's chief concerns, and I will grant him that this is an excellent design. But for me, it is paradoxically both very close and very far from perfection.

Root is my favourite game. The asymmetry between factions and how they all interact is an absolutely masterful design. It really is an ecosystem, and seeing the way all these mechanisms crash into each other in a different way every game just keeps me coming back. There's a ton of playstyles possible, even in the base game, and the political sandbox it provides allows for an incredible depth of varying approaches. All the expansions are fantastic, and there's genuinely infinite combinations of factions, maps, hirelings, card combos etc. It's pure interaction, both negative and positive, while still allowing for non-confrontational attempts. Every single game I look at this never before seen setup with glee. Kyle Ferrin's art is amazing here, and the screen printed meeples are perfect, although I do wish the faction boards were dual-layer.

Is it hard to learn? Certainly. Is there king making? Of course; that's a key part of a political war game. Are the factions unbalanced? For sure; this is a feature, not a bug. This gets the ball rolling on table talk from the very first turn, as someone is already in a much stronger position than other players. It's a game that requires multiple plays to really come to life. For me this is not a criticism; I keep a lean collection and I love the process of deep diving into one box, but this is not a game for everyone.

I guess my main critique is that Root is not made for low player counts. I'll play at 3, but 4-6 (with expansions) is where it shines. Root is best at 6, I'll die on that hill. Oh, and it can be sensitive. When players aren't willing to bash the leader, or decide to pick on a losing player who's help is needed in the rest of the woodland, the game's balance can get thrown out of whack, leading to runaway leaders, and disappointing first experiences. Not a problem with experienced players, but worth mentioning. This is a highly interactive game, so that comes with the territory. It also means online play is often terrible, because no one uses the chat.

Overall I can't say enough good things about Root, it really deserves all the hype that it's gotten; it's a brilliant game. I'll continue to pick up every expansion that's released, and I'll continue to look forward to exploring it after many, many plays. I even like the vagabond, no house rules needed.
